pros:
I chose to apply for a role at Step Change because I was sick and tired of working for a corporate bank whose only ambition was to create a profit for the shareholders. At Step Change, everything we do is geared towards helping people in desperate need of financial advice. Our help and support have helped save people's lives (as our clients tell us regularly). A couple of years ago, one of my friends disclosed they were struggling financially. He didn't know how he would tell his pregnant girlfriend - this was giving him anxiety, and he couldn't sleep. He knew I worked at Step Change and asked for my advice, it was simple "give us a call or go on our website, and we'll support you every step of the way". Fast forward two years, and he's on a debt solution and will be debt-free within three years. He couldn't be more thankful for the help Step Change provided him. THIS IS JOB SATISFACTION. 

I know from experience that other Leeds based organisations proactively identify their most engaged employees and ask them to complete positive GD reviews. They do this even just two weeks after joining their company (I mean, who isn't optimistic about their new role just two weeks in?). Step Change doesn't do anything like this - and maybe that's a bit naive, but at least it's more honest.

Some  people may have genuinely had a bad experience and left for valid reasons - that happens in every organisation - but I also think a large portion probably left under a cloud due to under performance or similar. There will also be people who have been here years and years who remember the charity as a small operation with 8% pay rises - those days are long gone. The Charity has had to become more commercial and that isn’t for everyone but some prefer to stick around and be negative rather than find a organisation more suitable for them.

Please remember, everyone's experience is relative to them. We're all inherently biased, and every review should be viewed through that lens. 

That said, alongside the extreme job satisfaction you get working at Step Change, the people are another huge positive. You'll struggle to find anyone at Step Change that doesn't genuinely care about helping people; that's why they joined in the first place. We have some proper laughs with each other, and I can genuinely say that some of my colleagues are now my best friends. 

I also couldn't have asked for more from a career development perspective, either. Suppose you are willing to put the work in and 'knock-on doors' that you want to open. In that case, you will find countless people willing to put in their own time to help you either through mentoring or introducing you to the right people within the business. Some people sit there waiting for someone to do it for them and then complain that they don't 'get developed'. We're all the masters of our own career, but it's great to have some help along the way - which you get at Step Change. 

I know I could probably get paid slightly higher elsewhere for what I do. Still, you can't put a price on working for a genuinely socially driven organisation, especially when you get to work with your friends every day and have a clear career path ahead of you. 

We've also just moved to a new office in Leeds, which feels like a great place to work, with lots of natural light and contemporary fixtures and fittings. The balance between working from home and in the office is excellent, especially when you genuinely enjoy being in such a friendly and smart environment.
cons:
Now for the not so good. 

Firstly, and this is an important point, Step Change is a not-for-profit organisation, so every penny counts and is carefully accounted for. Suppose you're coming from, say, a big corporate bank. In that case, you'll be used to (or maybe not) significant investments in technology that are delivered whenever needed. That is not the reality at Step Change. Don't get me wrong, we're improving things all the time, but there's only so much money to go around. It can be frustrating when the technology you need for your specific role gets pushed to the back of the queue by something else. That said, if you take a step back and look at the bigger picture, you will understand why that happened. It's generally because something needed to change for compliance or a change in regulation that meant systems in another team had to change. The result is that you sometimes have to work with slow and cumbersome tools, and I can understand why people get frustrated at this. Things are moving in the right direction, but the technology I use day-to-day is the only reason I've not given a 5-star rating. However, I expect this to change in the not too distant future. 

The other con I have is difficult to define, but let me try. Step Change is a charity for our clients i.e. we provide a free service to those who are most in need. Though Step Change is not a charity for employees, people shouldn't expect it to be. Many of the operational roles are traditional call centre-type roles. I think some people join and are surprised they have KPIs and performance targets. These targets make perfect sense as Step Change (like any other business) has to be as efficient as possible to break even at the end of the financial year and continue operating. So my advice is to join with your eyes open and understand that you will have performance targets to meet. If you don't meet them, you will be coached and performance managed, like in almost any similar business. pros:
Having worked at StepChange for a number of years I have a wealth of experience to provide a balance of the company/charity to future employees. 

Firstly, the people here are some of the most genuine, down to earth, caring people I've ever met. Lovely people and if you need support from your colleagues, you get it in spades. No backstabbing and in the four years I've spent here, I've never once had a problem or crossed word with anyone. I'm pretty easy going anyway, but even so! 

The job involves helping people in their hour of need...literally! You are doing one of the most valuable jobs in society. You get to talk to people from every walk of life, a window into other peoples lives. Very interesting work and you learn a lot!

The training is very good and the support put in place after training is exceptional.

The rewards package is competitive. 

Location is handy and close to all sorts of amenities. 

Work life balance is very good. You leave the work at the door on the way out. Dont underestimate the value of that! They offer flexible working options, a variety of shift patterns and you mostly get the holidays you request. 

If you work hard and are professional in your approach, you'll never really have any issues.
cons:
Unlike others, I wont start with the pay as this, for me, is not the most pressing of issues, although this does need addressing. 

For me, the issue of appreciation and respect comes far higher on the agenda than anything else. 

I have previously done a 'respected' public sector profession (one with letters after your name) and Debt Advice was a far more challenging role in many respects. In this previous life, I was given far more respect and trust from my seniors. This was a transition for me at StepChange and I can say that after several years in the job, I still didnt feel I was trusted or respected necessarily, maybe I was, I just never felt that way. This is a large part of job satisfaction and it's an area for development with StepChange. You are micromanaged and have no autonomy. 

A good deal of managers and team leaders know nothing other than StepChange and that's a shame. It's not their faults, they have been recruited into these roles and good on them! However, if managers have a diversified pool of work experience, they are better. They bring these different ideas and approaches to the company. Sort of...How do you know if next doors grass is greener, if you have never looked over the fence?! So unless StepChange begin to recruit outside talent into middle manager roles, or inside talent with previous work experience, it will stay as it is. I always got the impression that middle management didnt have the confidence to question or challenge those senior to them. But I think the young TLs are very keen to climb the ladder and attain a title and just lack the life experience...I get it. I've worked for some amazing time served managers in the past. They manage people and know how to get the best out of their team. Stepchange manage targets and numbers and weigh the pig. But you have to feed the pig for it to get fatter. You have to invest in your staff and the results will come. This leads to the next point...

You get more with sugar than you do with salt. Because of the relentless focus on targets, positive feedback is an add on. It's not integral to the charity. This isnt for a lack of trying, I do feel like the TLs do try to recognise people positively, but its things like monthly certificates, vouchers, shout outs which are gimmicky. The charity system of monitoring is, on balance, focussed on the negatives. Positive praise is just not readily given at Stepchange. If your numbers and targets say you didnt do a good job, you didnt do a good job, despite working so hard and dealing with incredibly difficult situations. Weeks like this can be hugely disappointing and really affect your outlook on the job. This is where the effective people managers would be useful! 

The pay is not reflective if the skill level and demanding nature of the job. This is an issue senior management need to address. They hugely underestimate the job and rely on independent companies drawing comparisons and making pay recommendations. Stepchange will not recruit or retain the calibre of talent the job requires by paying peanuts, and therefore will be on a merry-go-round of people leaving-people joining. All this at a huge cost to the charity's training operations. It could be amazing, but it's like a bus station of transient workers. You get what you pay for. 

It's not an easy place to progress. Theres no built in pay scale progression, although this is under review. You could be on the same pay grade for years, despite a wealth of knowledge and experience in the job.

review_title: Demoralising, providing a one size fits all poor service.
pros: You’re not alone in feeling objectified, dehumanised, taken advantage of and made to feel like a worthless lackey - so there’s always something to talk about with your colleagues.
cons:
I’ve been working at StepChange for over 10 years and have seen a horrific decline of a good workplace, not only in the way the organisation treats its staff but in the service provided to clients.

Where to start ... on the ‘frontlines’ ... StepChange used to provide a quality service at an individual level to clients. You called and spoke to someone who cared about you and your situation, you received advice from a knowledgeable individual that was tailored to your circumstances. You received probably the best service in the U.K. for free, depending upon that advice you would then choose a solution which may be administered by StepChange and if it was, you received probably the best aftercare in the U.K. throughout the administration of that solution.

Then things changed, gradually and for the worse. Initially it was replacing the system with one that introduced ‘decision logic’ - this took away some of the requirement for knowledge, gradually training followed suit and people became less skilled.

Then because of this and possibly as a precursor to an even newer system (transformation) the decision was made to ‘merge’ Helpline and Counselling resulting in many redundancies and a further reliance on ‘decision logic’ to provide solutions. Gradually this spread to the aftercare departments and the service you receive now is disgracefully woeful. It’s fair to say that if you contact StepChange now in the first instance, regardless of your circumstances, you will receive no advice, relief or anything worthwhile until you have been forced through a scripted scenario to go through all of your circumstances so the computer can tell you what to do. This also is now prevalent through aftercare too.

Throughout these changes, staff have been consistently lied to, year after year received token pay increases significantly lower than inflation and are subject to management (and grading) that is utterly subjective. No two members of staff are treated consistently - one person is ill and ends up on disciplinary, another is ill and is allowed to instead work from home therefore not being sick and avoiding any action related to that.

Departmental management is disgraceful. On the whole, clueless with no ability and a very definite ability to ‘fall up’ from any situation. In general having underlings do the work they then take credit for. I have experienced management that blatantly lies regarding many aspects of work and is called out on it - with no effect whatsoever, just a continuation of what they are doing.

I have personally suffered several occasions whereby a manager has disclosed personal information about me to others when they shouldn’t have, at one point this happened regularly over several weeks. I followed the correct procedure and raised a grievance with my manager, to be told they would take no action as they had spoken to them and they said the incidents didn’t occur. This despite having several witness statements confirming what had happened.

I have worked in both operational and non operational areas and certainly when working non operationally have been expected to work additional hours without pay, or reimbursement of hours. I Have been expected to carry out duties outside of my contract, including where these contravene Health and Safety law and have been publicly humiliated as a result of not carrying out these duties.

I won’t even comment on transformation except to say that much larger organisations have spent much less for bigger projects and delivered in a much shorter space of time (or even just actually delivered ...) £15 million on an online form is not a good investment just on its own, never mind adding redundancies and real terms pay cuts for existing staff for years to fund it.

Believe me (and the other reviews) - StepChange is not a good place to work.

review_title: Barely still a charity for clients, let alone its employees.
pros: To keep the wolf from the door.
cons:
Barely still a charity for clients, let alone its employees. 

That was my feeling after the first year or so. I’ve now reached five years.

Stepchange are a company masquerading as a not-for-profit for people in problem debt. As a debt advisor you’re really just a fancy debt collector for Stepchange. In turn Stepchange are a debt collector for the banks and creditors. This is reflected in the way repayment options are prioritised over insolvency options despite the latter often (usually) being better for the client. Why? Because Stepchange are funded by so-called ‘voluntary’ contributions from the credit industry. In English, this means that the banks and creditors give Stepchange back some of the money they receive through Debt Management Plans. This is a huge vested interest, a bit like McDonalds funding heart disease and cancer studies for diabetes charities and such like. 

The training is designed to facilitate this. Changes in policy, procedure and system process take away autonomy and decision-making. You’re turned into a human mouthpiece for what ‘the system’ decides. What the system decides is rarely in the interests of the client. It also makes employees on the frontline (debt advisors) expendable and replaced with absolute ease. Stepchange know this and treat staff with contempt. They set up in towns and cities where there aren’t any better call centre jobs. They role out near-annual employee engagement surveys. They try to skew the outcome (announcing a sudden pay rise days before the survey is released, for example). But the results are always the same. The key area that is highlighted every year (aside from the shocking remuneration package) is communication. This never improves and the management conduct themselves as if they’re working for MI5 and can’t divulge anything. On pay rises: there’s been one in line with inflation in all the years I’ve been here.

As a debt advisor, the job is reduced to this: input the client’s financial information onto a debt solution ‘price comparison style’ system, assess if they can repay their debts, then tell them about the solution that the computer thinks they should do. It’s almost always about making sure the big banks get their money back. Or trying to buy the client time and suspend their payments while they work to get themselves to a position where they can pay it back. Stepchange sees 10 years as a reasonable time to repay debts. That’s based purely on opinion. Even with Bankruptcy, you’re debt free in a year and it’s off your file after six. The training is all geared up to get the employee to improve their persuasion skills and get clients onto repayment plans. You’re taught 'active listening’ and told it’s to improve your empathy. You’re told to build rapport. You’re told and taught a variety of techniques that they say make your call about the client. What’s really happening is you’re being coached in how to use techniques like mirroring and labelling which are more appropriate for a hostage negotiation than are for people in debt who have their backs to the wall and are, understandably, terrified.

It’s also a perfect place for absolute career nihilism. Stepchange Debt Charity makes all the classic mistakes that lead to poor employee engagement and low overall job satisfaction. The charity is rotten to its core and in need of drastic change.  This overhaul is beyond the management capabilities of the current leaders. In my time at the company I’ve witnessed countless examples of colleagues who feel utterly anonymous and unrecognised. I’ve been there myself, feeling invisible and as if my potential and abilities are unwanted. You cannot grow as an individual or an employee. There’s no interest from above in any hopes and ambitions you might have. Worse still, the job often feels irrelevant. The charity is managed in such a way that you don’t even feel like a tiny nail in a board in the beams holding it all together. What should feel like a rewarding job where you help people to overcome financial strife ends up being a daily grind of fulfilling the charity’s vested interests.

The default position on sickness is one of fault with the employee. You’re made to feel as if you’re lying, as if you couldn’t possibly be sick, or injured, or mentally ill. Other reviews have gone into great detail about this but suffice to say - It’s all true. The sickness policy is beyond terrible.

All the high-profile campaigning Stepchange do (led by CEO Phil Andrew) is just designed to make it easier to flog debt management plans to clients. Thing like breathing space, for example. Let me assure you, nothing is about the client.
You might enjoy working here if you enjoyed being at school. You’ll be micro-managed and regimented. You’ll learn something new for six months or so. I can only speak for debt advice (there’s other departments, of course) but it’s a dull, boring and repetitive job. Again, it might suit someone who’s happy to plod and who doesn’t mind being patronised. Someone who doesn’t want to better themselves. Otherwise, look elsewhere. You don’t want to get stuck here!

And to the people who write reviews of their time at ‘charity’. Good on you - keep exposing it as the atrocious place to work that it is! Laura Carver, I look forward to your response to this soon!

pros:
Some really great people work at StepChange
Free Tea and Coffee
cons:
Working at StepChange is a nightmare, just a living one. 

It is common place to be shouted at, lied to, spoken to with no respect, or manners. This is behaviour done by individuals in the Senior Leadership Team (SLT) or the Executive Team (ET). People at the Charity are treated abhorrently, mainly by the SLT and ET. You only get anywhere if your face fits and you smile, nod and say yes. Challenge anyone on what is being done, or what is being proposed and your card is marked and you are out the door. Post a review on Glassdoor and it is seen as just a moan, or someone having a bad day, as opposed to the truth. The reviews on Glassdoor are correct. It is a toxic place to work, with a horrendous culture. Debt advisors are overworked, trying to meet difficult targets which just seem to get more stringent. 
 
Culture; there is no culture at StepChange. There is no spirit, or sense of Team. Individuals are not valued, appreciated or even thanked. There is a clique among the higher ranks, and Team Leaders do as they please. People are just repeatedly bullied, harassed and spoken to in a disgusting manner. If, a normal person, not in a management or leadership role, challenges behaviour, they are sacked instantly. There maybe a dignity at work policy, and a code of conduct, but no one actually follows that, and no one certainly leads by example. People who suffer with mental health issues are basically signing their own termination, as the sickness policy is a joke, with new proposals soon to be launched, reducing the current offering, to be in line with other organisations. This is the first place I have worked, where the sickness policy isn't geared up for anyone who actually has an illness, or longer term health condition. 
There is a blame culture, where those who are actually doing the do, are blamed, and used as a scapegoat. This is repeated over and over, and even communicated out, but then again, who wants to hear the truth right?  There is no support for employees, there is no honesty, and everything that is said is a lie. StepChange is not an organisation you should trust, and if you have any principles, then avoid, because you end up with none.
 
Let’s now focus on Transformation. The Charity has been undergoing a period of change. A lot of the Glassdoor reviews mention this change, and the newly implemented system. Well, this system is meant to be the be all and end all of the whole old systems, and is meant to do everything quicker, faster, with more ease. Again, more lies. The new system is poor. It takes longer to load, to complete the debt advice process, and no one enjoys using it. It is a nightmare to use when you have a client on the phone, and handling time is doubled if not more. Even the journey for clients who go online is horrendous, so much so, the online journey has been paused. Delivery dates were pushed out and out and out, but no one took any accountability. No one took responsibility. No one ever does. Money is thrown away on this new magical ‘can do everything’ system that clearly is not fit for purpose as it doesn’t work, and causes more issues than all of the old systems put together. Yet the new system is still pushed and pushed. Anyone would have thought StepChange had millions in its reserves, but who remembers that it is a Charity? Because it certainly doesn’t behave like one.  People lower down the ranks are blamed, used as a scapegoat and shamed into trying to work harder, faster, and are told to cut corners, to ‘just do it’, even if it is the wrong decision. The new system has so many work around, I'm surprised my colleagues can remember them all. But not one person in the SLT or Exec take responsibility, or accountability for the non-delivery of Projects. Despite some Projects and Programmes being owned by individuals in the Executive function for some months, or even years prior.
 
The Senior Leadership Team, and Executive Team, do not have any of the skills to lead and transform this organisation into a great place to work. In fact, none of the Senior Leadership Team actual lead anyone, instead it is a culture whereby people are managed out of the organisation due to fear. If you do this, or you don’t do this then you are sacked. Good people join the organisation and quickly leave as they are treated so poorly. StepChange does as it pleases. They rail road over people who are trying to do their job, and do it to the best of their ability. Decisions are made without any understanding or knowledge, and without consulting any of the Teams who have to deliver. 
 
If you want to aim high, and really earn your bonus (which is a pittance), then go for it. But know your scores are already decided by the Executive and Senior Leadership Team before you even have your end of year review. Even before the scores are calibrated, so makes a mockery of the whole end of year performance process. Why bother arguing why you deserve this that and the other, when someone who doesn’t even know you, argues how good or bad you are?
 
Overall, working for StepChange is soul destroying. Not only is it that, it is career suicide. I wish I could have given zero stars, but couldn’t even do that.

review_title: It's a charity, it must be good right?
pros:

cons:
Most call centres follow the same model of micro-managed target driven performance ratings but this is literally all there is at StepChange. You come to work, literally change people's lives, get told you're not performing and then you go home and it depresses the hell out of people. If you're lucky you might get a chocolate bar from the magic cupboard so you've got something to eat while you're crying but that's it. This might seem like a joke when it isn't.
Dept Advisors should be given gold plated, diamond encrusted gowns and placed on 100ft high pedestals for the work they do, really they should, but at best they're overlooked, at worst bullied and belittled, and be in no doubt about the fact that this will continue as it has for many many years.
Yes most call centre managers are focused on stats, but some of them are also focused on people; you have to thank people for the work they do every single day they do it, don't just ask the team leaders to do it and don't just send out a silly communication or launch a 'thank you' event that you read about in a people management text book 20 years ago. StepChange doesn't understand this at all. 
It's almost incomprehensible to think that praise is rarely given to people in this kind of job, but even when praise is given it's because by some random alignment of the stars your stats happen to be good this month, every last one of those stats, people don't genuinely believe it carries any meaning or that you're truly being thanked. It's a lifeless kind of praise that's given to you privately in a drab side-room at the far end of the floor. It can't be public praise because there's no time for esteem building amongst the team, certainly not around some hollow percentage score you've managed to hit. There is no time for public anything, team building is mentioned occasionally in passing or as a joke, but it doesn't exist because everyone must be kept on the phones at all times. The only time you get to speak with some people in your team is when you're shuffling awkwardly round the kitchen, desperately trying to make a cup of tea and find your soul. The call centre is deliberately understaffed and this is a hill that the charity is willing to die on.

'Clients are more important than anything else' is an interesting concept.

If you're 'lucky' enough to move into one of the back office roles like I was you'll find out how horribly cliquey the place is too, you can barely log into your computer without a bunch "morally pure" entities rolling their eyes at you. You'll also meet the people who've been 'managing' you for the first time and they are honestly some of the most awful managers you'll meet in your entire life. Demanding, inflexible and inhuman are some of the kindest words I can think of to describe the most, shall we say, well-known managers but let's not beat around the bush here, that small clique of managers are bullies, literally everyone knows who they are and they absolutely should not be in the positions they're in. The worst part is when you slowly realise that they have no introspection.
Everything that is wrong with the culture at StepChange is on them and rightly so.
The HR department are beyond hopeless, I practically begged them for help with homophobic bullying and harassment that I experienced in a back office role and they would not intervene, so there is no chance that they're going to be able to stand up to a bullying clique of managers.
Working here is soul-destroying and it would have ruined me if I hadn't left.

pros: The salary, the people, the holiday allowance and the health cover.
cons:
Boring role, with no progression, unless your face fits. Pay rises not based on excellent performance.  

Horrific sickness policy. No flexibility, so people with long term illnesses, mental health issues, children or who are carers, don’t get the support they need. 

HR polices are not written well and some team leaders don’t follow them correctly. There is no duty of care policy, which is unusual. HR don’t seem very experienced or know what they are doing.  It’s quite common for an employee to challenge a decision or policy, by using a union rep. They usually win. 

Departmental managers and above are the same core group of people, moving around, so change never happens.  This makes it very hard for team leaders who want to get a managers job. 

Team leaders have too many projects, so there is no time to lead, manage, coach or develop their staff. They are very stressed, with some working 50 hour weeks. They should be paid more and a project team should be employed, to do the projects. The charity probably won’t do this, due to cost. 

It’s quite common for team leaders to spend 36 hours a month in meetings and receive 250 emails a day. Some team leaders are brilliant and some are appalling. There is no consistency. You can be on a team where you get regular feedback, praise, motivation and one to ones. You can be on a team where this doesn’t happen. This is because some team leaders take on the role to get a higher paid job in IT or project management. This means they have no desire to manage people. Because they do a lot of project work for senior management and say yes to everything, they get away with poor people management. 


Changes are made, without asking the people doing the role, how this will impact the client and the job. This means they aren’t aware of potential issues, so when the  change goes live, it causes a lot of issues. It’s then left up to the employees to fix it. 

The training focuses on advice but not policies. This means new employees aren’t aware of the policies to follow and make a huge amount of mistakes. I’ve never worked anywhere with as many mistakes as this. It creates stress for the people fixing them and sometimes client complaints. 

The job relies too heavily on systems and scripts. This means inexperienced people, don’t really know what is best advice for a client or give detailed advice. It’s not always a great client experience. They just read the script. When the system goes down, they can’t do their job from memory. This is poor. 

The salary and benefits are excellent. The pay rises and maternity/paternity pay, are horrendous. Also the lack of reduced hours, means it’s hard to work here if you want to study, are a carer or have children. Some people do manage to get reduced hours but only by fighting it or getting a union rep in. Some people are too tired to fight, so just give in and accept the no. 

The call centre relies too heavily on stats and not the client experience. Everything is a box ticking exercise, to look good to senior management, because they’re scared of them. 

The way they deal with complaints and FCA regulation is perfect. They always follow the law and do everything by the book. The issue is there’s so much focus on clients, the employees become an afterthought. You’re just a bum on seat and a number. 

Overall some people genuinely care and will do anything to help you/clients. Unfortunately this is now a low percentage. The majority of people are just there for the money or because they’re too scared to leave. Some are there because they know they can get a high paid IT or project management job, without having the qualifications. 

The lack of care really shows every day. It’s reflected in a high sickness level, the horrendous staff turnover, low morale and feedback not being acted on. Most people are too stressed or tired to care. Some are just trying to leave and some just tick boxes to get ahead. This leaves the people who do care, de motivated and stressed, until they leave. It’s all very sad. I really did care, every day. 

This call centre could be an amazing place to work. It once was.
